author: Lucy Cormack
title: One in three pharmacists recommend herbal remedies with little scientific basis
text:
Pin to Pinterest PIN Link St John's Wort is a flowering plant which some studies have shown to be effective in the treatment of mild to moderate depression. 
Asked how it responded to the Choice investigation, a TerryWhite Chemmart spokeswoman said all its pharmacies were owned by pharmacists who were "highly trained and exist to serve the health needs of local community members. "Our pharmacists strive to deliver the best health outcomes for customers as a key part of the broader healthcare system and in collaboration with other trusted healthcare professionals," she said. 
A Priceline Pharmacy spokesman said its police was to encourage its specialist in-house pharmacists to give "only high quality and accurate health advice, based on the best available scientific and medical evidence". 
Chemist Warehouse has been contacted for comment. 
According to the Therapeutic Goods Association, all complementary medicines sold in Australia are monitored to ensure they are made from safe ingredients and manufactured in compliant premises. 
"As the TGA does not individually test these low risk medicines, the TGA cannot guarantee that they work," she said, adding that it conducted random and targeted testing of products and post-marketing follow up," a TGA spokeswoman said. 
"Complementary medicines cannot make serious health claims...However, the suppliers of these medicines are required by law to hold evidence of efficacy and when TGA finds the evidence is deficient it will cancel the product from supply." 
Last week the Pharmaceutical Society of Australia released its new Code of Ethics, which outlines the values of the pharmacy profession and expected standards of ethical behaviour towards individuals, the community and society. 
'Integrity principle 1' of the code refers to a pharmacist's obligation in recommending treatments, stating that they must provide "accurate, truthful, relevant, and independent information in a form that is appropriate for and not misleading to patients." 
The principle also requires that a pharmacist "will only purchase, supply or promote any medicine, complementary medicine, herbal remedy or other healthcare product where there is credible evidence of efficacy and the benefit of use outweighs the risk". 
The Pharmaceutical Society of Australia has been contacted for comment.
